name: Paroxetine (Paxil)
summary: Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, and other psychiatric conditions.
description: Paroxetine, marketed under the brand name Paxil among others, is an SSRI antidepressant that increases serotonin levels in the brain by inhibiting its reuptake into neurons. It is prescribed for major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder. It has a relatively short half-life compared to some other SSRIs, which can lead to withdrawal symptoms if discontinued abruptly.

contraindications: Concurrent use with MAO inhibitors or within 14 days of discontinuing MAOIs
Concurrent use with thioridazine or pimozide

sections.text: Paroxetine selectively inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) into presynaptic neurons, increasing serotonin availability in the synaptic cleft and enhancing serotonergic neurotransmission.

adult.Major Depressive Disorder: Initial: 20 mg orally once daily in the morning. May increase by 10 mg/week up to a maximum of 50 mg/day.
adult.Generalized Anxiety Disorder: Initial: 20 mg once daily; maximum 50 mg/day.
adult.Panic Disorder: Initial: 10 mg once daily; increase by 10 mg/week; usual range 20–40 mg/day; maximum 60 mg/day.
adult.OCD: Initial: 20 mg/day; may increase up to 60 mg/day.
adult.PMDD: 12.5–25 mg/day during luteal phase or continuously.

sections.elderly: Start at lower doses (10 mg/day) and titrate cautiously.

sections.text: Onset of symptom improvement may be observed within 1–2 weeks, with full therapeutic effects typically requiring 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults with major depressive disorder and other psychiatric disorders.
other: Avoid abrupt discontinuation; taper gradually to minimize withdrawal symptoms
May cause sexual side effects including decreased libido and delayed ejaculation
Use with caution in patients with seizure disorders

items: Electrolytes (risk of hyponatremia, especially in elderly)

sections.pregnancy: Category D – may cause fetal harm; use only if benefits outweigh risks.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; caution advised.
sections.pediatrics: Not approved for use in children and adolescents for depression.

sections.text: Gradually decrease dose over several weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, headache, irritability, and sensory disturbances.

items: Shorter half-life than some SSRIs; withdrawal symptoms more likely with missed doses.
Some patients experience more pronounced anticholinergic side effects compared to other SSRIs.
Low-dose Brisdelle formulation is approved for vasomotor symptoms of menopause.

seo.title: Paroxetine (Paxil) - Uses, Dosing, Side Effects, Interactions
seo.description: Paroxetine (Paxil) is an SSRI antidepressant used for depression, anxiety, OCD, PTSD, and PMDD. Learn dosing, side effects, interactions, and warnings.
